bindep.txt.message:
Ubuntu Jammy does still have python2 packages but they've been renamed from python* to python2*. For example python2-dev is a valid package name on Jammy.

Another way to approach this problem would be to use a couple lines like this:

  python-dev [platform:dpkg platform:apk !platform:ubuntu-jammy]
  python2-dev [platform:ubuntu-jammy]
  
This would allow you to continue testing python2 on modern ubuntu.

zuul/model.py.message:
Note for reviewers: the pipeline state that we change here locally is updated in Zookeeper either as a side-effect of e.g. queues being added/removed but at the latest when the pipeline state is set at the end of a pipeline run: https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul/src/branch/master/zuul/scheduler.py#L2232-L2233

The reason why this works is because the `_zkobject_hash` used for deciding whether to save the object or not, is calculated based on the original raw data from ZK.
I agree, I don't think we want that situation even if not fatal as it is the opposite of optimization even if it doesn't happen frequently. That seems fixable though.

I think currently it's not showing the behavior you described as we don't write the updated pipeline state to Zookeeper in any of the cleanup methods as far as I can see.

But since the cleanup methods acquire the pipeline lock they could potentially update the state in the future. So I think it makes sense to account for that.

Agreed.  I think I've come up with a solution that avoids the problem but generally maintains the same behavior without introducing any new delays.  So rather than ensuring that the layout is up to date, we just indicate to the refresh method that we don't care whether it is or not and it just loads the data as-is.

Agreed.  I think I've come up with a solution that avoids the problem but generally maintains the same behavior without introducing any new delays.  So rather than ensuring that the layout is up to date, we just indicate to the refresh method that we don't care whether it is or not and it just loads the data as-is.

Data here is coming from Zookeeper right? Wouldn't the uuid in zookeeper be the canonical version and not what we've got in memory? Otherwise you'd have multiple schedulers potentially fighting over updating this with different uuids?

Other way around: when we process the pipelines, we make sure that our local tenant layout is up to date first, then we refresh the pipeline state, and so if the layout uuid in ZK doesn't match, then we know that the pipeline state in ZK is out of date and needs to be refreshed.  So we "reset" it on the fly here.

Now, after having written that, it occurs to me that we refresh the pipeline state at two other times (both of them cleanup methods), and we do not ensure that our local layout state is the most current at the time, so there may be a race there where one scheduler performs a tenant reconfiguration and then also runs this method during a normal pipeline processing run and updates the pipeline state to the new layout, then another scheduler performs a node request cleanup (before it updates its layout), runs this method, and sees that the ZK pipeline state does not match the tenant layout and performs this reset.  I think that would essentially cause the pipeline state to flap and continually reset until all the schedulers got on the same page again.

I don't think it would be catastrophic or lose data, but I don't think it's what we want.

I think we need the cleanup methods to either abort or wait if the layout state doesn't match.
How about throwing an exception in the serialize() method when we have refreshed the pipeline as read-only?

nova/scheduler/request_filter.py.message:
... and that will not work :/ as later during the PCI claim we need to know which RP a request is fulfilled so that the PCI claim also allocate the same device or allocate VFs from the same parent PF.

So we need to know which RPs are fulfilling the request. And we can have multiple requests per instance and we have to distinguish between them. 
Also we have to handle the case where a single count > 1 request are fulfilled from more than on RP.

I only see one possible soluton:
1) create individual request group for each count (use the {request_id}-{i} as a group suffix
1.5) enforce group_policy=none to allow these groups to overlap
2) then we will have RP mapping for each group (i.e. each request and each count)
3) the PCI claim logic should look up the these PRs via the request's request_id and allocate devices based on the RP names that are pointing to (parent) device PCI address

for what its worth i think we shoudl deprecate this option and eventually remove it and only support non until we actually provide a new feature in placement to allow expressing group policy between specific groups.

you cant really use isolate properly today without hitting a bunch of edge cases

I agree with the long term goal to have group pair level policy. But in some limited cases `isolate` can be used to implement PF anti affinity for VFs and therefore network device redundancy. I.e. if no other resources end up in groups then isolate work for the VF groups. So I would keep them as an option until we have a better one.

controllerconfig/controllerconfig/upgrad.message:
Thinking about robustness...

Do we have a guarantee the directory is there after a restart?

If we don't have a guarantee for that:

1) I don't really want to mess with the path where docker is already behaving, leave the already good path as it is and do recovery logic only if in a bad state
Example of bad state is when /var/lib/docker/tmp is missing.

2) It would make more sense to loop the over a check and service restart several times


Maybe in general is just good if we don't change the existing good path (no restart if in good state)

So here might be worth changing to something like:

if [ -d /var/lib/docker/tmp ]; then
    log "Missing docker directories"
    systemctl restart docker

    while <loop a certain number of times>; do
       SVC_ACTIVE=$(systemctl is-active docker)
       [ $SVC_ACTIVE == "active" ] && break || log "Waiting docker service to become active..."
       sleep 5
    done
else
    log "Docker directories found, no need to restart"
fi

The general idea is above, but might have syntax errors and log messages are just examples and can be improved.

Have we seen this outside of upgrades? If this is a general docker issue and can happen at any point in time, maybe we should consider adding the check to the docker service file instead. Then we will be covered for all cases?

> Have we seen this outside of upgrades?

To the best of my knowledge this hasn't been seen outside of upgrades (at least not on fresh installs).

> maybe we should consider adding the check to the docker service file instead

Since adjusting docker would affect the system in all cases, not just upgrades, this more contained solution would be a safer option for the time being.

waitall() comes down to eventlet.event.Event.wait(). Reading the comment below, it seems to support multiple calls.

https://github.com/eventlet/eventlet/blob/85290a11dd5c5f511a45f4010b512eedfef87000/eventlet/event.py#L17-L18

But of course it is possible to modify GreenThreadPoolExecutor so that it will have the additional flag whether shutdown with wait=True is already called or not. Is it better to do so?

I missed checking about self.delayed_work.join() in the comment above, but yet this came down to eventlet.event.Event.wait() via eventlet.queue.Queue.join(), so the both two lines seems to be okay to be called many times.

and https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/b5e59b562329aaa0975e406e4669d3dbbef68d41  indeed is latest commit for master https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commits/branch/master

Tags for independent deliverables always refer to the master branch of the deliverable repository.

The master branch already exist https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient so you can't create a new one from a tag.

So, to release a new version for this deliverable you just have to:

```
  - version: 20.0.0
    projects:
      - repo: openstack/python-tripleoclient
        hash: b5e59b562329aaa0975e406e4669d3dbbef68d41
```

More or less as you suggested in your comment above.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
"But now n3000 reset failure is found when lockdown
is enabled."

Since you're using a Story/Task here and not a bug report, there is no good detailed explanation as to what this n3000 issue actually is.  We need a good explanation of the actual issue here eg. is there something wrong with the n3000 kernel module?  Why exactly is this reset failure occurring?  And why is the drastic measure of removing a security feature the right solution?  Just saying "because CentOS" is not a good enough answer, because the product should be evolving to be better anyway.

Let me see if I can help this along some more.

The Debian documentation for Secure Boot (https://wiki.debian.org/SecureBoot) indicates that the use of SB activates "lockdown" mode in the kernel. "lockdown" disabled various features that can be used to modify the kernel (see list at the link I provided).

So as reviewers Jim and I have questions which the current commit log doesn't answer.

1. Is Secure Boot still being used? as the Debian docs indicate SB and "lockdown" go hand in hand.

2. With "lockdown" not being in place does this then open the possibility of removing the restrictions of modifying the kernel?

3. Why is the n3000 special? document this as well as the effects which make this solution the right approach.

Lastly you can link this configuration to what we had in CentOS, this is good to know but we are quickly approach a point where what we did in CentOS should not be dictating what we do in the future.

Thanks.

I agree with Jim. This is an extraordinary measure to take for a single device. The commit log needs to do a better job of describing the negative impact on security that this change has, or if there is none, then say as much.

I would prefer to see the n3000 support removed if we are compromising security for StarlingX.

OK, so it is the rsu tool.  What is it doing that requires being able to modify the kernel?  Do you mean the super-rsu command?

"super-rsu is a tool that can be used for flashing image files and commanding an Intel PAC device to perform RSU (remote system update - or a board reboot). Performing an RSU on an Intel PAC device will cause it to reload any firmware or programmable logic and restart its execution, a requirement for any updated firmware or programmable logic to take effect."

Help us to understand further what is going on here.  Does initial boot work, but a subsequent reset of the n3000 fails because reloading the firmware or programmable logic doesn't work?
Done

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Need much better explanations for the problem and why this solution is the right thing to do.  Also will need Mark A to approve this solution.

Here is the history of lockdown feature:
When we brought up kernel from linux-yocto to debian stx, we followed those rules:
keep the config aligned with centos stx kernel;
remove all the debian specific patches for kernel (unless they are necessary for debian build framework).

In this way, the lockdown feature shouldn't be enabled.
"The use of SB activates lockdown mode in the kernel" exists in the debian specific kernel patches. I don't think it is necessary for secure boot.
I add it here only for the extra kernel module signature checking feature mentioned in the git log and not for any consideration of security.

The main work about secure boot is in boot process. Now the only reason that cause issues reported after boot about secure boot should be this lockdown feature for us.

I myself suggest remove it. 

Anyway, I'm checking with engineers about the container image "registry.local:9001/docker.io/starlingx/n3000-opae:stx.8.0-v1.0.2", where this issue is triggered from.
I pushed this patchset to turn it from a task to a bug, so that more details of the issue can be found at: https://bugs.launchpad.net/starlingx/+bug/1998418 .

For those following along we have had offline discussions with folks on the TSC and we can proceed with disabling lockdown.

Wtih the updates to the commit log which now appear to cover in proper detail the situation I can sign off on this.

OK, so now we know what is going on ie. a call to rsu to reset the device, which will fail if in lockdown.  Probably because they are using some kind of "less than ideal" approach by accessing the device via user space or some other unorthodox way.

But Mark's questions are still outstanding.  He will have to bless this approach of turning off lockdown before I will review.

I was talking about a different implementation by Bogdan (see [1] and [2]). This adds the logic to ignore '0' into tripleo-ansible and make t-h-t always pass IronicWorkers.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/866163/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/866177

Sorry ignore my previous comment. I was looking at a wrong tab. I was saying [1] and [2] would be better, because omitting the variable should be done when rendering ansible variables.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/866292/2/deployment/ironic/ironic-api-container-puppet.yaml#383
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/866290

> such "omit", but that heat's limitation should be handled within 

There is no heat limitation. Doing below[1] would omit the ansible var and handle the default case. If we're intending to move away all logic (including conditionals) from THT to ansible (which seems to be the case with all standalone work till date) that's a different thing and it would surely make ansible logic complicated and we probably don't care about ansible performance. So I've no concrete opinion on this atm.

[1]
tripleo_ironic_api_httpd_vhost_workers:
  if:
    - ironic_workers_set
    - {get_param: IronicWorkers}

> There is no heat limitation. Doing below[1] would omit the ansible var and handle the default case.

What I was saying is that heat does not support soemthing like default: omit and we need that if-logic to omit the variable, which Bogdan does not like having in tht. If we expect the same usage(pass worker:0 by default, when user does not configure the option) from edpm operators then I agree with having this logic in t-a but as long as the default 0 is specific to tht then I'd keep the logic in tht.

I left the comment in my t-a patch but adding more complicated logic in ansible to simplify t-h-t is not desired, and we should keep t-a, especially these service standalone roles, as general as possible.

In case you run tripleo-ansible independently then you can use omit which is more ansible-native. Current problem is that heat does not provide the way to define such "omit", but that heat's limitation should be handled within tht, IMO.

Why do we need something like default: omit from heat or pass worker:0 to ansible? Not setting the var (which heat would do) and checking for "tripleo_ironic_api_httpd_vhost_workers is defined" should do what you want in ansible, right?

cinder/volume/drivers/rbd.py.message: my understanding of what this did was it resized the object in the rbd backend to be the size of the requested cinder volume -- I think we still need to do this?

That's a good question because that resize call it's the source of all this bug. The source of all this trouble is RBD doesn't share the real size of their volumes to cinder when using encryption, and we have our reasons I guess. The main example is: An encrypted RBD volume in the backend is 1026M but Cinder still shows 1024M or 1G.

Before calling _copy_image_to_volume cinder creates the encrypted volume A. After that in L1670 _encrypt_image converts the source glance image to an encrypted random file in a tmp dir. Then the driver imports that data into the the volume A in L1687. Finally volume.size shows 1G but actually it takes up more space in the backend. Then resize() truncates data but doesn't fail when doing so. After that we try to create an instance from that volume but boot fails and Cinder doesn't show errors or warnings.

Finally, one important thing to know is that the API checks that the image size is smaller than the requested volume size.

I'm having trouble understanding this section.  My understanding of the bug is:
- if the glance image is < n GiB, a user can request that it be created as a volume of size n
- but the image "grows" when it's encrypted as a luks container
- so if the image is 100b less than n GiB, the user can ask for a size n volume ... but if the luks header is 1000b, then the resulting rbd object is n GiB + 900b which cannot fit in an n GiB volume

            if volume.size * units.Gi - image_size > 1 * units.Gi:

I don't understand your concern. Your link [1] pertains to configuring the haproxy for the internal g-api at a DCN/Edge site. The code directs merely directs puppet to use the glance_api_edge_node_ips (the Edge addresses) rather than the glance_api_internal_node_ips (which will be the ones in the controlplane).

In case this information helps, I did extensive testing of a DCN/Edge deployment (using RHOSP 17).

The ServiceNetMap defines <service>Network settings for every service, and most of them specify the internal_api network (or fall back to ctlplane). All of the glance services (GlanceApi, GlanceApiEdge and GlanceApiInternal) want to use the internal_api network.

The reason for the LP bug is I messed up the ServiceNetMap entry. "GlanceApiEdgeInternalNetwork" is wrong, because it doesn't follow the <service>Network pattern. This causes tripleo-ansible to set the glance_api_internal_node_ips to ctlplane addresses. See [2] and note it wants to use the <service>_network, and falls base to default('ctlplane')

[2] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_hieradata/templates/all_nodes.j2#L8

In the case of DCN/Edge, we want the glance haproxy to include only Edge nodes (glance_api_edge_node_ips) and *not* every glance instance on the internal_api network. All of the glance services are on the internal_api network, but the intent is that Edge sites only use their local instances (the ones at that site).

Alan/John/Steve, though we've decided to go with this patch, I think there is a big issue with it (which I probably failed to make clearly earlier).

With the current way it's implemented, GlanceAPIInternal service uses config_settings[1] from GlanceApi and hence the bind_host ip[2] for it would be from GlanceApiNetwork. If someone provides a different network in ServiceNetMap for GlanceApiInternal, it would break the deployment as the service would be listening on a different network(GlanceApiNetwork) than what HaProxy backend is configured for(GlanceApiInternalNetwork).

So the other patch was more appropriate unless you want to re-implement GlanceAPIInternal service after this patch.

As for the redundant ServiceNetMap entries are concerned, they won't have any impact and can be cleaned up later.

My -1 is still valid here and we still have time to change the decision;)

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/glance/glance-api-internal-container-puppet.yaml#L103

[2] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/blob/master/deployment/glance/glance-api-container-puppet.yaml#L576
